contents.text:
Student topics: github copilot
Weekly study hours: 6
Duration in weeks: 8

Produce JSON only matching the provided schema

arguments.query: GitHub Copilot, AI-powered coding, coding assistance, AI developer tools

content.text:
{"results":[{"title":"Get started with GitHub Copilot","content":"# Get started with GitHub Copilot
Welcome to GitHub Copilot, your AI companion in Visual Studio!
Copilot helps you code faster and with greater accuracy by suggesting entire lines or blocks of code, answering questions, and assisting with routine tasks such as writing unit tests, debugging, and profiling. You can use all these features directly in your Visual Studio environment.
In this article, you learn how to use Copilot and make the most of its features in Visual Studio.
## Launch Copilot
1. Launch Visual Studio (version 17.8 or later). *Update to the latest version of Visual Studio to get the most out of Copilot.*
2. Create a new project, open an existing project, or continue without code to launch the IDE.
3. Select the **GitHub Copilot** badge in the upper right corner of Visual Studio, and select **Open Chat Window**.
 ![Screenshot showing the GitHub Copilot badge in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/visualstudio/copilot-badge-open-chat-window.png?view=visualstudio)
 If Copilot isn't installed, select **Install Copilot** from the dropdown and follow the installer prompts. For more information, see [Manage Copilot installation and state](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-install-and-states?view=visualstudio).
4. In the Chat window, enter a prompt to start using Copilot.
 If you're not already signed in with a GitHub account, Visual Studio prompts you to sign in. You can also [get started with Copilot Free](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-free-plan?view=visualstudio) if you don't have a Copilot subscription. Complete the sign-in or sign-up process in your browser, and then return to Visual Studio.
![Screenshot showing the Get Started with Copilot Free dialog in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/visualstudio/visual-studio-github-copilot-chat/get-started-with-copilot-free-dialog.png?view=visualstudio)
Copilot is now ready to use in Visual Studio!","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-get-started?view=visualstudio"},{"title":"Get started with GitHub Copilot","content":"# Get started with GitHub Copilot
## Start using Copilot
After you sign in, use Copilot in the Chat window and throughout the IDE.
1. **Use [Agent mode](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-agent-mode?view=visualstudio) and [MCP](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/mcp-servers?view=visualstudio)**: In the Chat window, select **Ask** and switch to **Agent** to enable agent mode. Use the tools icon to access MCP, configure servers, and choose which tools Copilot can use. For example, send "Write unit tests for the methods in this file" to get Copilot assistance with generating targeted code.
2. **Use [Completions](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension?view=visualstudio) and [Next Edit Suggestions](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-next-edit-suggestions?view=visualstudio)**: As you code, Copilot provides suggestions directly in the editor. Copilot suggests both new code (shown as gray text) and edits to existing code.
3. **Use Copilot actions across Visual Studio**: Find Copilot-powered actions and suggestions in the editor context menu, Error List, Feature Search, and other areas of the IDE.
## Tailor Copilot Chat to your workflow
Customize Copilot for your project and your development workflow.
1. **Manage [context with references](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-chat-context-references?view=visualstudio)**: Use the **+** button to attach additional context, such as files, images, or ask Copilot to reference your entire solution.
2. **Access different [models](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-usage-and-models?view=visualstudio#understand-model-selection)**: Use the model picker in the prompt window to select AI models, or [bring your own model](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-select-add-models?view=visualstudio#bring-your-own-model-byom) to Copilot! Explore different models for different scenarios, whether it's answering quick questions, writing documentation, or generating multi-file code edits.
3. **Add custom instructions**: Add reusable [custom instructions](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-chat-context?view=visualstudio#use-custom-instructions) in `.github/copilot-instructions.md` and [prompt files](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-chat-context?view=visualstudio#use-prompt-files) in `.github/prompts` to customize Copilot’s responses for your coding style or project needs.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-get-started?view=visualstudio#start-using-copilot"},{"title":"Get started with GitHub Copilot completions","content":"# Get started with GitHub Copilot completions
GitHub Copilot acts as an AI-powered pair programmer for Visual Studio that provides you with context-aware code completions, suggestions, and even entire code snippets. It provides these suggestions directly in the editor while you write your code, and it can work with a broad range of programming languages and frameworks.
Copilot provides two kinds of inline suggestions, both of which take your existing code into account:
1. **Completions** - As you type in the editor, Copilot provides ghost text suggestions with colorized syntax highlighting at your current cursor location.
2. **Next edit suggestions** - Based on your current editing patterns, NES predicts both where your next code edit will be and what changes you'll make.
## How GitHub Copilot works
GitHub Copilot works by using advanced machine-learning models trained on a vast dataset of publicly available code from GitHub repositories. As you type code, AI analyzes the context and provides relevant suggestions in real time. You can also receive suggestions by writing a comment in natural language that describes what you want the code to do.
![Animated screenshot that shows code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/vs-2022/github-copilot-extension-example.gif?view=visualstudio)
You can also use GitHub Copilot to convert comments to code, create unit tests, create SQL queries, and more.
## Prerequisites
1. [Visual Studio 2026](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/releases/2026/release-notes) or [Visual Studio 2022 version 17.14](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/releases/2022/release-history) (with the latest servicing release recommended for the most up-to-date features)
2. [Sign in to Visual Studio by using a GitHub account](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/work-with-github-accounts?view=visualstudio) with [Copilot access](https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/about-github-copilot/what-is-github-copilot#getting-access-to-copilot).
  If you don't yet have a Copilot subscription, you can use [Copilot for free](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-free-plan?view=visualstudio) by signing up for the Copilot Free plan and get a monthly limit of inline suggestions and chat interactions.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension?view=visualstudio"},{"title":"Get Started with GitHub Copilot - Training","content":"# Get started with GitHub Copilot

- Module
- 14 Units

 Intermediate 

 Developer 

 GitHub 

This module introduces developers to the GitHub Copilot products, the benefits that GitHub Copilot provides to developers, the GitHub Copilot and GitHub Copilot Chat product features, and the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code.

##  Learning objectives 

By the end of this module, you'll be able to:

- Explain what GitHub Copilot is and the advantages it provides.
- Install the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code.
- Explain the features of the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code and how to use them.
- Configure the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code.

## Prerequisites

- An active subscription for GitHub Copilot is required for either your personal GitHub account or a GitHub account managed by an organization or enterprise. You can set up a GitHub Copilot Free plan or sign-up for a GitHub Copilot Pro subscription with a one-time 30-day free trial. For this training, signing up for a GitHub Copilot Free plan is sufficient.
- Awareness of the GitHub Copilot free trial conditions: if you choose the 30-day free trial offer for GitHub Copilot Pro, a form of payment is requested at sign-up. Charges aren't applied until the trial is over, unless you cancel before the conclusion of the 30-day period.

Take the module assessment

 Module Assessment Results

Assess your understanding of this module. Sign in and answer all questions correctly to earn a pass designation on your profile.

- [Introduction](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/1-introduction)
- [Examine AI tools from GitHub, OpenAI, and Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/2-examine-ai-assisted-programming-tools)
- [Compare GitHub Copilot plans](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/3-compare-github-copilot-plans)
- [Review GitHub Copilot features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/4-review-github-copilot-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot's setup process](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/5-examine-github-copilot-setup-process)
- [Configure GitHub Copilot settings in Visual Studio Code](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/6-configure-github-copilot-settings-visual-studio-code)
- [Manage GitHub Copilot policies, features, and extensions for individuals](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/7-manage-github-copilot-policies-features-extensions)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot's code completion features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/8-examine-github-copilot-code-completion-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot's AI assistance features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/9-examine-github-copilot-ai-assistance-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot Chat view features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/10-examine-chat-view-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot inline chat, smart actions, and quick chat](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/11-examine-inline-chat-smart-actions-quick-chat)
- [Exercise - Examine GitHub Copilot settings and user interface features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/12-exercise-examine-github-copilot-settings-interface)
- [Module assessment](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/13-knowledge-check)
- [Summary](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/14-summary)

Take the module assessment

 Module Assessment Results

Assess your understanding of this module. Sign in and answer all questions correctly to earn a pass designation on your profile.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/"},{"title":"GitHub Copilot extension: Overview","content":"# GitHub Copilot extension: Overview
## How GitHub Copilot works
GitHub Copilot works by utilizing advanced machine learning models trained on a vast dataset of publicly available code from GitHub repositories. As you type code, the AI analyzes the context and provides relevant suggestions in real-time. You can receive suggestions also by writing a natural language comment describing what you want the code to do.
The GitHub Copilot extension in Azure Data Studio uses context from the editor to provide suggestions. For example, if you're writing a query that joins two tables, GitHub Copilot suggests the join condition from columns in the open editor, other files in the workspace, and common syntax patterns.
## Privacy
Your code is yours. We follow responsible practices in accordance with our [Privacy Statement](https://docs.github.com/site-policy/privacy-policies/github-privacy-statement) to ensure that your code snippets aren't used as suggested code for other users of GitHub Copilot.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure-data-studio/extensions/github-copilot-extension-overview#how-github-copilot-works"},{"title":"Use GitHub Copilot to create WinUI / Windows App SDK apps in Visual Studio","content":"# Use GitHub Copilot to create WinUI / Windows App SDK apps in Visual Studio
## Use GitHub Copilot
### Autocomplete your code snippets
GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio provides real-time code suggestions and completions based on the code you write. The most straightforward way to use Copilot is to start typing code in the editor, and Copilot will try to autocomplete your code snippet. You can then accept or dismiss the suggestions:
![Screenshot that shows the code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot (basic autocomplete).](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/1-basic-autocomplete.png)
Tip
If you don't see the GitHub Copilot suggestions, you can enable different aspects of the feature in Visual Studio's options under `Tools` -> `Options` -> `GitHub` -> `Copilot`.
### Ask Copilot for suggestions
Right-click in the code editor and select `Ask Copilot`. A prompt window will open where you can chat inline with Copilot to get a list of suggestions based on the current cursor position and your prompt:
![Screenshot that shows the inline prompting capabilities of GitHub Copilot.](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/2-generate-multiple-suggestions.png)
### Prompt Copilot with plain-language comments
Although Copilot is used primarily for code completion, you can also use natural language comments to guide Copilot in generating specific code snippets. For example, you can use comments to request a specific feature or functionality:
![Screenshot that shows the code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot (prompting).](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/3-prompt-copilot-with-inline-comment.png)
### Use temporary comments to add code from other files to Copilot's context
If you're working on a code-behind file and want Copilot to incorporate context from the associated XAML file, you can use temporary comments to include this additional code within Copilot's context. Here's an example of how you can specify the XAML code first, and then have Copilot generate the corresponding C# code:
![Screenshot that shows the code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot (context expansion).](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/4-add-context-temporary-comments.png)
### Ask Copilot to explain how something works with inline comments
You can use inline comments to ask Copilot to explain how a specific piece of code works. This is similar to using the inline Ask Copilot feature or the Copilot Chat window, except your prompt is typed directly into the code editor:","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/github-copilot-winui-vs#use-github-copilot"},{"title":"What is GitHub Copilot for Azure?","content":"# What is GitHub Copilot for Azure?
GitHub Copilot for Azure is a GitHub Copilot extension that enables developers to use natural language to:
1. Learn about Azure features.
2. Deploy Azure resources.
3. Get information about Azure resources.
4. Diagnose and troubleshoot problems with Azure resources.
You must have access to an Azure subscription and be subscribed to GitHub Copilot. [Get started](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/get-started) using the extension.
GitHub Copilot is designed to help developers, including developers new to Azure, to be more productive as quickly as possible. For experienced Azure users, GitHub Copilot for Azure replaces the need to:
1. memorize or look up Azure CLI commands and arguments.
2. create complex deployment scripts by hand.
3. sign in and browse through the Azure portal.
## How it works
GitHub Copilot for Azure supplements the general knowledge of a foundational large language model (LLM) like GPT-5 and Claude Sonnet 4 with tool calling using the **Azure Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server** that enables interaction with Azure services, systems, and Azure Resource Graph to carry out specific tasks on your behalf. Over [35 Azure services](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/azure-mcp-server/tools/) are already available and more services and capabilities are being added regularly. Learn more about the capabilities of [Azure MCP Server](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/azure-mcp-server/overview).","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/introduction"},{"title":"Get started with GitHub Copilot for Azure (visual-studio-2022)","content":"# Get started with GitHub Copilot for Azure (visual-studio-2022)
## Install GitHub Copilot for Azure
1. In Visual Studio 2022, in the Extensions menu, select Manage Extensions.
2. In the Extension Manager search for and select **GitHub Copilot for Azure (VS 2022)**. Select the **Install** button.
3. After a moment, you'll see a banner: "Your changes are scheduled. The modifications will begin when Microsoft Visual Studio is closed." Shut down Visual Studio.
4. The VSIX Installer dialog opens confirming the installation. Select the **Modify** button.
5. After a few moments, you should see "Modifications Complete". Select the **Close** button.
6. Reopen Visual Studio 2022.
7. Select the "GitHub Copilot" button in upper-right of window on the toolbar. Select **Open Chat Window**.
8. When the GitHub Copilot Chat window appears, in the chat area at the bottom, select **Agent** mode, then select the **Select tools** button (two wrenches).
9. In the **Select tools** dialog, you should see "Azure MCP Server". To the right, you see "0/153" if no tools are selected (which is currently the default). Select the parent node to choose all of the tools.
Important
If you do not see "Azure MCP Server" in the list of tools, you may need to uninstall and re-install the extension.
## Write your first prompt
1. If the Chat window isn't already open, make sure it's open by selecting the **View** > **GitHub Copilot Chat** menu option. You should see chat window docked to the right side by default.
 ![Screenshot that shows the GitHub Copilot Chat window in Visual Studio 2022.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/media/get-started/visual-studio-2022-chat-window.png)
2. In the chat text area at the bottom of the chat pane, enter the following prompt:
```prompt
 Do I have any resources currently running?
```
 ![Screenshot that shows an example prompt typed into the chat area in Visual Studio 2022.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/media/get-started/visual-studio-2022-first-prompt.png)
By default, GitHub Copilot uses **ask** mode. Ask mode provides answers to your prompts in the chat pane. **Agent** mode enables GitHub Copilot to take action in your workspace.
The answer to your question depends on what's currently running in Azure in your subscription.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/get-started#install-github-copilot-for-azure"},{"title":"Use GitHub Copilot","content":"# Use GitHub Copilot
## IntelliSense, Code Snippets, GitHub Copilot
When you develop your code in Azure Data Studio, you have three assistants to help you:
1. [IntelliSense](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/using-intellisense)
2. [Create and use code snippets to quickly create Transact-SQL (T-SQL) scripts in Azure Data Studio](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure-data-studio/code-snippets)
3. [GitHub Copilot](https://github.com/features/copilot)
Consider these assistants as an extra pair of hands that work independently. It's crucial to understand the difference between them, and when to use them.
| Assistant | Overview | Activation and deactivation| 
|  --- | --- | ---  |
| **IntelliSense** | Feature in Azure Data Studio code editor that provides suggestion for code completion, parameter info, and object names. | Enabled by default in Azure Data Studio. To deactivate, Go to Settings or press `Ctrl` + `,`, type IntelliSense and uncheck the boxes as per requirement. |
| **Code Snippets** | Mini T-SQL code templates that are inbuilt or custom made, which assist with generating proper code syntax. | Enabled by default in Azure Data Studio. To deactivate, Go to Settings or press `Ctrl` + `,`, type Snippets and uncheck the boxes as per requirement. |
| **GitHub Copilot** | AI powered pair programmer extension that provides context-aware code completions, suggestions, and even entire code snippets. | Comes with the GitHub Copilot Extension in a subscription model. Can activate from Copilot status icon present in Azure Data Studio status bar. |

## Privacy
Your code is yours. We follow responsible practices in accordance with our [Privacy Statement](https://docs.github.com/site-policy/privacy-policies/github-privacy-statement) to ensure that your code snippets aren't used as suggested code for other users of GitHub Copilot.","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/azure-data-studio/extensions/github-copilot-extension-using-github-copilot#intellisense,-code-snippets,-github-copilot"},{"title":"Get started with GitHub Copilot completions","content":"# Get started with GitHub Copilot completions
## Get your first code completions
As you type code or comments in the editor, GitHub Copilot provides ghost text code suggestions: sometimes the completion of the current line, sometimes a whole new block of code. You can accept all, or part of a suggestion, or you can keep typing and ignore the suggestions.
GitHub Copilot provides suggestions for numerous languages, including (but not limited to) C#, C++, and Python. The following examples are in C#, but other languages work similarly.
1. Open Visual Studio and create a new C# project.
2. Open a C# file (`Program.cs`) in the code editor.
3. In the editor, enter a comment or a method signature to see inline code suggestions from Copilot.
```csharp
     // method to add two numbers
```
```csharp
     int subtractNumbers(
```
4. Press Enter to open the GitHub Copilot command palette.
 To accept the suggestion, select the Tab key. To reject the suggestion, select the Esc key or continue typing.
 ![Screenshot that shows suggestions to accept or modify a GitHub Copilot code suggestion in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/visualstudio/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/copilot-accept-code-suggestions.png?view=visualstudio)
5. Add the following code to see completions from Copilot:
```csharp
     int a = 5;
     int b = 10;
     int sum
```
 ![Animated screenshot that shows the use of the GitHub Copilot completions in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/vs-2022/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/github-copilot-whole-line-completions.gif?view=visualstudio)
## Generate documentation comments
To use automatic generation of documentation comments on your C++ or C# project file, type the comment pattern according to your configuration (for example, `///`). Copilot instantly completes the function description based on the function's content.
[![Animated screenshot that shows the automatic generation of documentation comments from Copilot.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/vs-2022/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/doc-comments-generation.gif?view=visualstudio)](media/vs-2022/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/doc-comments-generation.gif?view=visualstudio#lightbox)","contentUrl":"https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension?view=visualstudio#get-your-first-code-completions"}]}

results.title: Get started with GitHub Copilot
results.content:
# Get started with GitHub Copilot
Welcome to GitHub Copilot, your AI companion in Visual Studio!
Copilot helps you code faster and with greater accuracy by suggesting entire lines or blocks of code, answering questions, and assisting with routine tasks such as writing unit tests, debugging, and profiling. You can use all these features directly in your Visual Studio environment.
In this article, you learn how to use Copilot and make the most of its features in Visual Studio.
## Launch Copilot
1. Launch Visual Studio (version 17.8 or later). *Update to the latest version of Visual Studio to get the most out of Copilot.*
2. Create a new project, open an existing project, or continue without code to launch the IDE.
3. Select the **GitHub Copilot** badge in the upper right corner of Visual Studio, and select **Open Chat Window**.
 ![Screenshot showing the GitHub Copilot badge in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/visualstudio/copilot-badge-open-chat-window.png?view=visualstudio)
 If Copilot isn't installed, select **Install Copilot** from the dropdown and follow the installer prompts. For more information, see [Manage Copilot installation and state](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-install-and-states?view=visualstudio).
4. In the Chat window, enter a prompt to start using Copilot.
 If you're not already signed in with a GitHub account, Visual Studio prompts you to sign in. You can also [get started with Copilot Free](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-free-plan?view=visualstudio) if you don't have a Copilot subscription. Complete the sign-in or sign-up process in your browser, and then return to Visual Studio.
![Screenshot showing the Get Started with Copilot Free dialog in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/visualstudio/visual-studio-github-copilot-chat/get-started-with-copilot-free-dialog.png?view=visualstudio)
Copilot is now ready to use in Visual Studio!

results.title: Get started with GitHub Copilot
results.content:
# Get started with GitHub Copilot
## Start using Copilot
After you sign in, use Copilot in the Chat window and throughout the IDE.
1. **Use [Agent mode](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-agent-mode?view=visualstudio) and [MCP](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/mcp-servers?view=visualstudio)**: In the Chat window, select **Ask** and switch to **Agent** to enable agent mode. Use the tools icon to access MCP, configure servers, and choose which tools Copilot can use. For example, send "Write unit tests for the methods in this file" to get Copilot assistance with generating targeted code.
2. **Use [Completions](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension?view=visualstudio) and [Next Edit Suggestions](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-next-edit-suggestions?view=visualstudio)**: As you code, Copilot provides suggestions directly in the editor. Copilot suggests both new code (shown as gray text) and edits to existing code.
3. **Use Copilot actions across Visual Studio**: Find Copilot-powered actions and suggestions in the editor context menu, Error List, Feature Search, and other areas of the IDE.
## Tailor Copilot Chat to your workflow
Customize Copilot for your project and your development workflow.
1. **Manage [context with references](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-chat-context-references?view=visualstudio)**: Use the **+** button to attach additional context, such as files, images, or ask Copilot to reference your entire solution.
2. **Access different [models](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-usage-and-models?view=visualstudio#understand-model-selection)**: Use the model picker in the prompt window to select AI models, or [bring your own model](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-select-add-models?view=visualstudio#bring-your-own-model-byom) to Copilot! Explore different models for different scenarios, whether it's answering quick questions, writing documentation, or generating multi-file code edits.
3. **Add custom instructions**: Add reusable [custom instructions](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-chat-context?view=visualstudio#use-custom-instructions) in `.github/copilot-instructions.md` and [prompt files](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-chat-context?view=visualstudio#use-prompt-files) in `.github/prompts` to customize Copilot’s responses for your coding style or project needs.

results.title: Get started with GitHub Copilot completions
results.content:
# Get started with GitHub Copilot completions
GitHub Copilot acts as an AI-powered pair programmer for Visual Studio that provides you with context-aware code completions, suggestions, and even entire code snippets. It provides these suggestions directly in the editor while you write your code, and it can work with a broad range of programming languages and frameworks.
Copilot provides two kinds of inline suggestions, both of which take your existing code into account:
1. **Completions** - As you type in the editor, Copilot provides ghost text suggestions with colorized syntax highlighting at your current cursor location.
2. **Next edit suggestions** - Based on your current editing patterns, NES predicts both where your next code edit will be and what changes you'll make.
## How GitHub Copilot works
GitHub Copilot works by using advanced machine-learning models trained on a vast dataset of publicly available code from GitHub repositories. As you type code, AI analyzes the context and provides relevant suggestions in real time. You can also receive suggestions by writing a comment in natural language that describes what you want the code to do.
![Animated screenshot that shows code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/vs-2022/github-copilot-extension-example.gif?view=visualstudio)
You can also use GitHub Copilot to convert comments to code, create unit tests, create SQL queries, and more.
## Prerequisites
1. [Visual Studio 2026](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/releases/2026/release-notes) or [Visual Studio 2022 version 17.14](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/releases/2022/release-history) (with the latest servicing release recommended for the most up-to-date features)
2. [Sign in to Visual Studio by using a GitHub account](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/work-with-github-accounts?view=visualstudio) with [Copilot access](https://docs.github.com/en/copilot/about-github-copilot/what-is-github-copilot#getting-access-to-copilot).
  If you don't yet have a Copilot subscription, you can use [Copilot for free](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/copilot-free-plan?view=visualstudio) by signing up for the Copilot Free plan and get a monthly limit of inline suggestions and chat interactions.

results.title: Get Started with GitHub Copilot - Training
results.content:
# Get started with GitHub Copilot

- Module
- 14 Units

 Intermediate 

 Developer 

 GitHub 

This module introduces developers to the GitHub Copilot products, the benefits that GitHub Copilot provides to developers, the GitHub Copilot and GitHub Copilot Chat product features, and the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code.

##  Learning objectives 

By the end of this module, you'll be able to:

- Explain what GitHub Copilot is and the advantages it provides.
- Install the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code.
- Explain the features of the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code and how to use them.
- Configure the GitHub Copilot extensions for Visual Studio Code.

## Prerequisites

- An active subscription for GitHub Copilot is required for either your personal GitHub account or a GitHub account managed by an organization or enterprise. You can set up a GitHub Copilot Free plan or sign-up for a GitHub Copilot Pro subscription with a one-time 30-day free trial. For this training, signing up for a GitHub Copilot Free plan is sufficient.
- Awareness of the GitHub Copilot free trial conditions: if you choose the 30-day free trial offer for GitHub Copilot Pro, a form of payment is requested at sign-up. Charges aren't applied until the trial is over, unless you cancel before the conclusion of the 30-day period.

Take the module assessment

 Module Assessment Results

Assess your understanding of this module. Sign in and answer all questions correctly to earn a pass designation on your profile.

- [Introduction](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/1-introduction)
- [Examine AI tools from GitHub, OpenAI, and Microsoft](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/2-examine-ai-assisted-programming-tools)
- [Compare GitHub Copilot plans](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/3-compare-github-copilot-plans)
- [Review GitHub Copilot features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/4-review-github-copilot-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot's setup process](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/5-examine-github-copilot-setup-process)
- [Configure GitHub Copilot settings in Visual Studio Code](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/6-configure-github-copilot-settings-visual-studio-code)
- [Manage GitHub Copilot policies, features, and extensions for individuals](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/7-manage-github-copilot-policies-features-extensions)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot's code completion features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/8-examine-github-copilot-code-completion-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot's AI assistance features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/9-examine-github-copilot-ai-assistance-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot Chat view features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/10-examine-chat-view-features)
- [Examine GitHub Copilot inline chat, smart actions, and quick chat](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/11-examine-inline-chat-smart-actions-quick-chat)
- [Exercise - Examine GitHub Copilot settings and user interface features](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/12-exercise-examine-github-copilot-settings-interface)
- [Module assessment](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/13-knowledge-check)
- [Summary](https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/14-summary)

Take the module assessment

 Module Assessment Results

Assess your understanding of this module. Sign in and answer all questions correctly to earn a pass designation on your profile.

results.title: GitHub Copilot extension: Overview
results.content:
# GitHub Copilot extension: Overview
## How GitHub Copilot works
GitHub Copilot works by utilizing advanced machine learning models trained on a vast dataset of publicly available code from GitHub repositories. As you type code, the AI analyzes the context and provides relevant suggestions in real-time. You can receive suggestions also by writing a natural language comment describing what you want the code to do.
The GitHub Copilot extension in Azure Data Studio uses context from the editor to provide suggestions. For example, if you're writing a query that joins two tables, GitHub Copilot suggests the join condition from columns in the open editor, other files in the workspace, and common syntax patterns.
## Privacy
Your code is yours. We follow responsible practices in accordance with our [Privacy Statement](https://docs.github.com/site-policy/privacy-policies/github-privacy-statement) to ensure that your code snippets aren't used as suggested code for other users of GitHub Copilot.

results.title: Use GitHub Copilot to create WinUI / Windows App SDK apps in Visual Studio
results.content:
# Use GitHub Copilot to create WinUI / Windows App SDK apps in Visual Studio
## Use GitHub Copilot
### Autocomplete your code snippets
GitHub Copilot in Visual Studio provides real-time code suggestions and completions based on the code you write. The most straightforward way to use Copilot is to start typing code in the editor, and Copilot will try to autocomplete your code snippet. You can then accept or dismiss the suggestions:
![Screenshot that shows the code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot (basic autocomplete).](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/1-basic-autocomplete.png)
Tip
If you don't see the GitHub Copilot suggestions, you can enable different aspects of the feature in Visual Studio's options under `Tools` -> `Options` -> `GitHub` -> `Copilot`.
### Ask Copilot for suggestions
Right-click in the code editor and select `Ask Copilot`. A prompt window will open where you can chat inline with Copilot to get a list of suggestions based on the current cursor position and your prompt:
![Screenshot that shows the inline prompting capabilities of GitHub Copilot.](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/2-generate-multiple-suggestions.png)
### Prompt Copilot with plain-language comments
Although Copilot is used primarily for code completion, you can also use natural language comments to guide Copilot in generating specific code snippets. For example, you can use comments to request a specific feature or functionality:
![Screenshot that shows the code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot (prompting).](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/3-prompt-copilot-with-inline-comment.png)
### Use temporary comments to add code from other files to Copilot's context
If you're working on a code-behind file and want Copilot to incorporate context from the associated XAML file, you can use temporary comments to include this additional code within Copilot's context. Here's an example of how you can specify the XAML code first, and then have Copilot generate the corresponding C# code:
![Screenshot that shows the code completion capabilities of GitHub Copilot (context expansion).](https://learn.microsoft.com/windows/apps/how-tos/images/github-copilot-winui-vs/4-add-context-temporary-comments.png)
### Ask Copilot to explain how something works with inline comments
You can use inline comments to ask Copilot to explain how a specific piece of code works. This is similar to using the inline Ask Copilot feature or the Copilot Chat window, except your prompt is typed directly into the code editor:

results.title: What is GitHub Copilot for Azure?
results.content:
# What is GitHub Copilot for Azure?
GitHub Copilot for Azure is a GitHub Copilot extension that enables developers to use natural language to:
1. Learn about Azure features.
2. Deploy Azure resources.
3. Get information about Azure resources.
4. Diagnose and troubleshoot problems with Azure resources.
You must have access to an Azure subscription and be subscribed to GitHub Copilot. [Get started](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/get-started) using the extension.
GitHub Copilot is designed to help developers, including developers new to Azure, to be more productive as quickly as possible. For experienced Azure users, GitHub Copilot for Azure replaces the need to:
1. memorize or look up Azure CLI commands and arguments.
2. create complex deployment scripts by hand.
3. sign in and browse through the Azure portal.
## How it works
GitHub Copilot for Azure supplements the general knowledge of a foundational large language model (LLM) like GPT-5 and Claude Sonnet 4 with tool calling using the **Azure Model Context Protocol (MCP) Server** that enables interaction with Azure services, systems, and Azure Resource Graph to carry out specific tasks on your behalf. Over [35 Azure services](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/azure-mcp-server/tools/) are already available and more services and capabilities are being added regularly. Learn more about the capabilities of [Azure MCP Server](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/azure-mcp-server/overview).

results.title: Get started with GitHub Copilot for Azure (visual-studio-2022)
results.content:
# Get started with GitHub Copilot for Azure (visual-studio-2022)
## Install GitHub Copilot for Azure
1. In Visual Studio 2022, in the Extensions menu, select Manage Extensions.
2. In the Extension Manager search for and select **GitHub Copilot for Azure (VS 2022)**. Select the **Install** button.
3. After a moment, you'll see a banner: "Your changes are scheduled. The modifications will begin when Microsoft Visual Studio is closed." Shut down Visual Studio.
4. The VSIX Installer dialog opens confirming the installation. Select the **Modify** button.
5. After a few moments, you should see "Modifications Complete". Select the **Close** button.
6. Reopen Visual Studio 2022.
7. Select the "GitHub Copilot" button in upper-right of window on the toolbar. Select **Open Chat Window**.
8. When the GitHub Copilot Chat window appears, in the chat area at the bottom, select **Agent** mode, then select the **Select tools** button (two wrenches).
9. In the **Select tools** dialog, you should see "Azure MCP Server". To the right, you see "0/153" if no tools are selected (which is currently the default). Select the parent node to choose all of the tools.
Important
If you do not see "Azure MCP Server" in the list of tools, you may need to uninstall and re-install the extension.
## Write your first prompt
1. If the Chat window isn't already open, make sure it's open by selecting the **View** > **GitHub Copilot Chat** menu option. You should see chat window docked to the right side by default.
 ![Screenshot that shows the GitHub Copilot Chat window in Visual Studio 2022.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/media/get-started/visual-studio-2022-chat-window.png)
2. In the chat text area at the bottom of the chat pane, enter the following prompt:
```prompt
 Do I have any resources currently running?
```
 ![Screenshot that shows an example prompt typed into the chat area in Visual Studio 2022.](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure/developer/github-copilot-azure/media/get-started/visual-studio-2022-first-prompt.png)
By default, GitHub Copilot uses **ask** mode. Ask mode provides answers to your prompts in the chat pane. **Agent** mode enables GitHub Copilot to take action in your workspace.
The answer to your question depends on what's currently running in Azure in your subscription.

results.title: Use GitHub Copilot
results.content:
# Use GitHub Copilot
## IntelliSense, Code Snippets, GitHub Copilot
When you develop your code in Azure Data Studio, you have three assistants to help you:
1. [IntelliSense](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/visualstudio/ide/using-intellisense)
2. [Create and use code snippets to quickly create Transact-SQL (T-SQL) scripts in Azure Data Studio](https://learn.microsoft.com/azure-data-studio/code-snippets)
3. [GitHub Copilot](https://github.com/features/copilot)
Consider these assistants as an extra pair of hands that work independently. It's crucial to understand the difference between them, and when to use them.
| Assistant | Overview | Activation and deactivation| 
|  --- | --- | ---  |
| **IntelliSense** | Feature in Azure Data Studio code editor that provides suggestion for code completion, parameter info, and object names. | Enabled by default in Azure Data Studio. To deactivate, Go to Settings or press `Ctrl` + `,`, type IntelliSense and uncheck the boxes as per requirement. |
| **Code Snippets** | Mini T-SQL code templates that are inbuilt or custom made, which assist with generating proper code syntax. | Enabled by default in Azure Data Studio. To deactivate, Go to Settings or press `Ctrl` + `,`, type Snippets and uncheck the boxes as per requirement. |
| **GitHub Copilot** | AI powered pair programmer extension that provides context-aware code completions, suggestions, and even entire code snippets. | Comes with the GitHub Copilot Extension in a subscription model. Can activate from Copilot status icon present in Azure Data Studio status bar. |

## Privacy
Your code is yours. We follow responsible practices in accordance with our [Privacy Statement](https://docs.github.com/site-policy/privacy-policies/github-privacy-statement) to ensure that your code snippets aren't used as suggested code for other users of GitHub Copilot.

results.title: Get started with GitHub Copilot completions
results.content:
# Get started with GitHub Copilot completions
## Get your first code completions
As you type code or comments in the editor, GitHub Copilot provides ghost text code suggestions: sometimes the completion of the current line, sometimes a whole new block of code. You can accept all, or part of a suggestion, or you can keep typing and ignore the suggestions.
GitHub Copilot provides suggestions for numerous languages, including (but not limited to) C#, C++, and Python. The following examples are in C#, but other languages work similarly.
1. Open Visual Studio and create a new C# project.
2. Open a C# file (`Program.cs`) in the code editor.
3. In the editor, enter a comment or a method signature to see inline code suggestions from Copilot.
```csharp
     // method to add two numbers
```
```csharp
     int subtractNumbers(
```
4. Press Enter to open the GitHub Copilot command palette.
 To accept the suggestion, select the Tab key. To reject the suggestion, select the Esc key or continue typing.
 ![Screenshot that shows suggestions to accept or modify a GitHub Copilot code suggestion in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/visualstudio/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/copilot-accept-code-suggestions.png?view=visualstudio)
5. Add the following code to see completions from Copilot:
```csharp
     int a = 5;
     int b = 10;
     int sum
```
 ![Animated screenshot that shows the use of the GitHub Copilot completions in Visual Studio.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/vs-2022/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/github-copilot-whole-line-completions.gif?view=visualstudio)
## Generate documentation comments
To use automatic generation of documentation comments on your C++ or C# project file, type the comment pattern according to your configuration (for example, `///`). Copilot instantly completes the function description based on the function's content.
[![Animated screenshot that shows the automatic generation of documentation comments from Copilot.](https://learn.microsoft.com/visualstudio/ide/media/vs-2022/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/doc-comments-generation.gif?view=visualstudio)](media/vs-2022/visual-studio-github-copilot-extension/doc-comments-generation.gif?view=visualstudio#lightbox)

      "id": "certification.ai-business-professional",
      "locale": "en-us",
      "title": "Microsoft Certified: AI Business Professional",
      "subtitle": "As a candidate for this Microsoft Certification, you should have experience using generative AI‑powered productivity tools, including Microsoft 365 Copilot, Researcher, and Analyst. You take advantage of AI to improve daily work, drive business outcomes, and make informed decisions in business contexts—without building AI apps or writing code.\n\nYou should have a basic understanding of Microsoft 365 and should be comfortable navigating core apps, such as Outlook, Word, Microsoft Teams, PowerPoint, and Excel. You should also be familiar with common business processes, including drafting emails, creating presentations, generating images, and managing documents.",
      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/credentials/certifications/ai-business-professional/",
      "iconUrl": "https://learn.microsoft.com/media/learn/certification/badges/ai-business-professional.svg",
      "type": "certification",
      "certificationType": "business",
      "exams": null,
      "levels": [
        "beginner"
      ],
      "roles": [
        "administrator",
        "business-user"
      ],
      "products": [
        "microsoft-365-copilot"
      ],
      "subjects": [
        "artificial-intelligence"
      ],
      "studyGuide": null,
      "renewalFrequencyInDays": 0,
      "prerequisites": [],
      "updatedAt": "2026-01-28T20:59:00+00:00"
    },
    {
      "id": "certification.agentic-ai-business-solutions-architect",
      "locale": "en-us",
      "title": "Microsoft Certified: Agentic AI Business Solutions Architect",
      "subtitle": "As a candidate for this certification, you’re an accomplished solution architect with expertise in designing and delivering AI‑driven business solutions that transform business processes and foster innovation. You’re experienced in creating scalable, secure, and integrated solutions that use multiple Microsoft services to address complex organizational challenges.\n\nYour competencies include:\n- Expertise in architecting solutions that use AI, including generative AI and various Foundry Tools tailored to meet business objectives.\n- Ability to design agentic‑first solutions.\n- Skills in designing multi‑agent orchestrated solutions.\n- Experience designing secure and scalable cross‑platform AI solutions.\n- Comprehensive knowledge of core Dynamics 365 products, Microsoft Power Platform, Microsoft Copilot Studio, Microsoft Foundry Tools, and Foundry Models.\n- Proficiency in working with agents created by using Copilot Studio, AI prompts, Microsoft Foundry, and working knowledge of multiple language models to create intelligent solutions.\n- Proficiency in adopting frameworks and delivering measurable outcomes aligned with enterprise success metrics and architecture patterns.\n- Expertise in working with open standards and protocols, including Agent2Agent (A2A) and Model Context Protocol (MCP).\n- Expertise in responsible AI practices, helping to ensure compliance and advocating for the Microsoft responsible AI guidelines.\n- Strong leadership in orchestrating AI features in Microsoft business applications to optimize operations and unlock growth opportunities.\n- Skills in securing AI models and data workflows, including detecting and resolving vulnerabilities, enforcing data residency and access controls, safeguarding model tuning, tracking changes, maintaining audit trails, and defending against prompt manipulation.\n- Experience in monitoring agent performance and interpreting telemetry data to help ensure reliability, optimize behavior, and drive continuous improvement.\n- Ability to conduct a return‑on‑investment (ROI) analysis of an AI‑powered solution.\n\nYour key responsibilities include:\n- Envisioning and defining architecture strategies to integrate AI and agents into business solutions.\n- Defining the roadmap for agentic‑first business processes.\n- Analyzing and interpreting business and technical requirements to architect comprehensive solutions.\n- Designing and prototyping AI components and showcasing transformative capabilities.\n- Guiding the end‑to‑end implementation of AI‑centric solutions, helping to ensure security, scalability, and alignment with organizational goals.\n- Promoting and championing the adoption of AI technologies in the development lifecycle and across business units.\n- Creating a cohesive application lifecycle management (ALM) strategy for agentic‑first solutions.\n- Creating a cohesive environment strategy for AI‑powered solutions, with consideration for third‑party AI solutions.\n- Guiding organizations on their way to becoming AI‑forward companies.\n\nAs an AI‑first solution architect, you lead the transformation of enterprise operations by envisioning and implementing AI‑powered architecture. With a focus on making the most of the full spectrum of Microsoft AI apps and services, along with business application tools, you drive innovation and help to ensure the delivery of impactful AI‑powered solutions.\n\n**To become a Microsoft Certified: Agentic AI Business Solutions Architect, you must earn at least one of the following prerequisites:**\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365 Business Central Developer Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365 Business Central Functional Consultant Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365 Customer Experience Analyst Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365 Customer Service Functional Consultant Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365 Field Service Functional Consultant Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365 Finance Functional Consultant Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365 Supply Chain Management Functional Consultant Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Dynamics 365: Finance and Operations Apps Developer Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Power Platform Functional Consultant Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Power Platform Developer Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Power Automate RPA Developer Associate\n- Microsoft Certified: Azure AI Engineer Associate\n\n**TIP**\n- Review the [AB-100 study guide](https://aka.ms/AB100-StudyGuide) to help you prepare for the exam.\n- Demo the exam experience by visiting our [exam sandbox](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=2226877).\n- The Practice Assessment for this exam is not currently available. Practice Assessments are usually available within 8 weeks of the exam being out of beta and generally available.",
      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/credentials/certifications/agentic-ai-business-solutions-architect/",
      "iconUrl": "https://learn.microsoft.com/media/learn/certification/badges/microsoft-certified-expert-badge.svg",
      "type": "certification",
      "certificationType": "role-based",
      "exams": null,
      "levels": [
        "advanced"
      ],
      "roles": [
        "solution-architect"
      ],
      "products": [
        "ai-builder"
      ],
      "subjects": [
        "artificial-intelligence"
      ],
      "studyGuide": null,
      "renewalFrequencyInDays": 365,
      "prerequisites": [],
      "updatedAt": "2026-02-04T20:07:00+00:00"
    },
    {
      "id": "certification.azure-ai-engineer",
      "locale": "en-us",
      "title": "Microsoft Certified: Azure AI Engineer Associate",
      "subtitle": "As a Microsoft Azure AI engineer, you build, manage, and deploy AI solutions that leverage Azure AI.\n\nYour responsibilities include participating in all phases of AI solutions development, including:\n- Requirements definition and design\n- Development\n- Deployment\n- Integration\n- Maintenance\n- Performance tuning\n- Monitoring\n\nYou work with solution architects to translate their vision. You also work with data scientists, data engineers, Internet of Things (IoT) specialists, infrastructure administrators, and other software developers to:\n- Build complete and secure end‑to‑end AI solutions.\n- Integrate AI capabilities in other applications and solutions.\n\nAs an Azure AI engineer, you have experience developing solutions that use languages such as:\n- Python\n- C#\n\nYou should be able to use Representational State Transfer (REST) APIs and SDKs to build secure image processing, video processing, natural language processing, knowledge mining, and generative AI solutions on Azure. You should:\n- Understand the components that make up the Azure AI portfolio and the available data storage options.\n- Be able to apply responsible AI principles.",
      "url": "https://learn.microsoft.com/credentials/certifications/azure-ai-engineer/",
      "iconUrl": "https://learn.microsoft.com/media/learn/certification/badges/microsoft-certified-associate-badge.svg",
      "type": "certification",
      "certificationType": "role-based",
      "exams": null,
      "levels": [
        "intermediate"
      ],
      "roles": [
        "ai-engineer"
      ],
      "products": [
        "azure"
      ],
      "subjects": [
        "artificial-intelligence"
      ],
      "studyGuide": null,
      "renewalFrequencyInDays": 365,
      "prerequisites": [],

    }
  ]
}

arguments.query: GitHub Copilot, AI-powered coding, Copilot features, Copilot in Visual Studio Code, prompt engineering, responsible AI use, coding efficiency, code suggestions, integration into development workflow, productivity boosting, privacy safeguards, introduction to using Copilot in coding projects, beginner and intermediate developers looking to master GitHub Copilot.

contents.text: {"rationale":"The student's goal is to become proficient in using GitHub Copilot for coding efficiency, AI-powered suggestions, and responsible use within modern development environments. The top Microsoft Learn module for these skills is 'Get Started with GitHub Copilot,' which introduces Copilot, its setup, features, and best practices; this aligns precisely with the student's time commitment and interest. Currently, there are no comprehensive learning paths solely focused on Copilot, but the provided module is detailed and covers both beginner and intermediate needs. Several relevant certifications also exist, especially the new 'GitHub Copilot' fundamentals badge, which validates practical Copilot use and responsible AI application.","learningPaths":[{"title":"Get Started with GitHub Copilot - Training","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/","estimatedHours":4,"relevance":"This is the most focused, practical, and up-to-date training directly addressing GitHub Copilot, teaching setup, usage, productivity strategies, code completion, prompt engineering, and security/privacy considerations."}],"modules":[{"title":"Get Started with GitHub Copilot","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/training/modules/get-started-github-copilot/","skillFocus":"Comprehensive Copilot setup, feature overview, usage within Visual Studio Code, productivity, security, and AI best practices."}],"targets":[{"title":"GitHub Copilot Certification","type":"Certification","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/credentials/certifications/github-copilot/"},{"title":"GitHub Foundations","type":"Certification","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/credentials/certifications/github-foundations/"},{"title":"Microsoft Certified: Azure AI Engineer Associate","type":"Certification","url":"https://learn.microsoft.com/credentials/certifications/azure-ai-engineer/"}]}
